Power series

So far the examples we have considered have been about summing sequences of numbers. But it is also possible to think about summing sequences of algebraic expressions, for example

\[ 1+x+x^2+x^3+\cdots. \]

A power series is a series of the form \[\sum_{n=0}^\infty c_nx^n=c_0+c_1x+c_2x^2+c_3x^3+\cdots\] where \(x\) is a variable and the coefficients \(c_n\) are constants.

The issue here is that depending on the value of \(x\), such a series may or may not converge. So, we will often want to know the set of \(x\) values for which the power series converges.


Many of the examples we will meet rely on the formula for a geometric series. Recall that \[ \sum\limits_{n=0}^\infty ar^n = \frac{a}{1-r}\mbox{ where } -1< r < 1 \] if \(r\) is outside these limits, then the series diverges. Also, if we take \(a = 1, r = x\) this series becomes \[ \sum\limits_{n=0}^\infty x^n = \frac{1}{1-x}\mbox{ where } -1< x < 1. \] Therefore if we had the function \(f(x) = \frac{1}{1-x}\) then we can represent this function with the power series \(\sum\limits_{n=0}^\infty x^n\).


Example

Express \(\dfrac{1}{2+x}\) as a power series. For which \(x\) does the series converge?

Solution

We have \(\dfrac{1}{2+x}=\dfrac{1}{2-(-x)}=\dfrac{1/2}{1-(-x/2)}\). So \(a=\frac12\) and \(r=-\frac{x}{2}\).So written as a power series,  \[ \dfrac{1}{2+x}=\sum_{k=0}^\infty ar^k =\sum_{k=0}^\infty \frac12\left(-\frac12x\right)^k. \] The series converges if \(|r|<1\), hence when \(\left|-\frac12x\right|<1\). This gives \[\begin{align*}\left|-\tfrac12\right|\left|x\right|&<1 \\ \tfrac12|x|&<1 \\ |x|&<2,\end{align*}\] thus \(-2<x<2\).
